segment.source: Windows 10 deployment considerations (Windows 10)
segment.target: Windows 10 deployment considerations (Windows 10)

segment.source: There are new deployment options in Windows 10 that help you simplify the deployment process and automate migration of existing settings and applications.
segment.target: There are new deployment options in Windows 10 that help you simplify the deployment process and automate migration of existing settings and applications.

segment.source: Windows 10 deployment considerations
segment.target: Windows 10 deployment considerations

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: There are new deployment options in Windows 10 that help you simplify the deployment process and automate migration of existing settings and applications.
segment.target: There are new deployment options in Windows 10 that help you simplify the deployment process and automate migration of existing settings and applications.

segment.source: For many years, organizations have deployed new versions of Windows using a “wipe and load” deployment process.
segment.target: For many years, organizations have deployed new versions of Windows using a “wipe and load” deployment process.

segment.source: At a high level, this process captures existing data and settings from the existing device, deploys a new custom-built Windows image to a PC, injects hardware drivers, reinstalls applications, and finally restores the data and settings.
segment.target: At a high level, this process captures existing data and settings from the existing device, deploys a new custom-built Windows image to a PC, injects hardware drivers, reinstalls applications, and finally restores the data and settings.

segment.source: With Windows 10, this process is still fully supported, and for some deployment scenarios is still necessary.
segment.target: With Windows 10, this process is still fully supported, and for some deployment scenarios is still necessary.

segment.source: Windows 10 also introduces two additional scenarios that organizations should consider:
segment.target: Windows 10 also introduces two additional scenarios that organizations should consider:

segment.source: In-place upgrade, which provides a simple, automated process that leverages the Windows setup process to automatically upgrade from an earlier version of Windows.
segment.target: In-place upgrade, which provides a simple, automated process that leverages the Windows setup process to automatically upgrade from an earlier version of Windows.

segment.source: This process automatically migrates existing data, settings, drivers, and applications.
segment.target: This process automatically migrates existing data, settings, drivers, and applications.

segment.source: Dynamic provisioning, which enables organizations to configure new Windows 10 devices for organization use without having to deploy a new custom organization image to the device.
segment.target: Dynamic provisioning, which enables organizations to configure new Windows 10 devices for organization use without having to deploy a new custom organization image to the device.

segment.source: Both of these scenarios eliminate the image creation process altogether, which can greatly simplify the deployment process.
segment.target: Both of these scenarios eliminate the image creation process altogether, which can greatly simplify the deployment process.

segment.source: So how do you choose?
segment.target: So how do you choose?

segment.source: At a high level:
segment.target: At a high level:

segment.source: Consider ...
segment.target: Consider ...

segment.source: For these scenarios
segment.target: For these scenarios

segment.source: In-place upgrade
segment.target: In-place upgrade

segment.source: When you want to keep all (or at least most) existing applications
segment.target: When you want to keep all (or at least most) existing applications

segment.source: When you do not plan to significantly change the device configuration (for example, BIOS to UEFI) or operating system configuration (for example, x86 to x64, language changes, Administrators to non-Administrators, Active Directory domain consolidations)
segment.target: When you do not plan to significantly change the device configuration (for example, BIOS to UEFI) or operating system configuration (for example, x86 to x64, language changes, Administrators to non-Administrators, Active Directory domain consolidations)

segment.source: To migrate from Windows 10 to a later Windows 10 release
segment.target: To migrate from Windows 10 to a later Windows 10 release

segment.source: Traditional wipe-and-load
segment.target: Traditional wipe-and-load

segment.source: When you upgrade significant numbers of applications along with the new Windows OS
segment.target: When you upgrade significant numbers of applications along with the new Windows OS

segment.source: When you make significant device or operating system configuration changes
segment.target: When you make significant device or operating system configuration changes

segment.source: When you “start clean”.
segment.target: When you “start clean”.

segment.source: For example, scenarios where it is not necessary to preserve existing apps or data (for example, call centers) or when you move from unmanaged to well-managed PCs
segment.target: For example, scenarios where it is not necessary to preserve existing apps or data (for example, call centers) or when you move from unmanaged to well-managed PCs

segment.source: When you migrate from Windows Vista or other previous operating system versions
segment.target: When you migrate from Windows Vista or other previous operating system versions

segment.source: Dynamic provisioning
segment.target: Dynamic provisioning

segment.source: For new devices, especially in “choose your own device” scenarios when simple configuration (not reimaging) is all that is required
segment.target: For new devices, especially in “choose your own device” scenarios when simple configuration (not reimaging) is all that is required

segment.source: When used in combination with a management tool (for example, an MDM service like Microsoft Intune) that enables self-service installation of user-specific or role-specific apps
segment.target: When used in combination with a management tool (for example, an MDM service like Microsoft Intune) that enables self-service installation of user-specific or role-specific apps

segment.source: Migration from previous Windows versions
segment.target: Migration from previous Windows versions

segment.source: For existing PCs running Windows 7 or Windows 8.1, in-place upgrade is the recommended method for Windows 10 deployment and should be used whenever possible.
segment.target: For existing PCs running Windows 7 or Windows 8.1, in-place upgrade is the recommended method for Windows 10 deployment and should be used whenever possible.

segment.source: Although wipe-and-load (OS refresh) deployments are still fully supported (and necessary in some scenarios, as mentioned previously), in-place upgrade is simpler and faster, and enables a faster Windows 10 deployment overall.
segment.target: Although wipe-and-load (OS refresh) deployments are still fully supported (and necessary in some scenarios, as mentioned previously), in-place upgrade is simpler and faster, and enables a faster Windows 10 deployment overall.

segment.source: Note that the original Windows 8 release is only supported until January 2016.
segment.target: Note that the original Windows 8 release is only supported until January 2016.

segment.source: Organizations that do not think they can complete a full Windows 10 migration by that date should deploy Windows 8.1 now and consider Windows 10 after Windows 8 has been removed from the environment.
segment.target: Organizations that do not think they can complete a full Windows 10 migration by that date should deploy Windows 8.1 now and consider Windows 10 after Windows 8 has been removed from the environment.

segment.source: For existing Windows PCs running Windows Vista, you can perform wipe-and-load (OS refresh) deployments when you use compatible hardware.
segment.target: For existing Windows PCs running Windows Vista, you can perform wipe-and-load (OS refresh) deployments when you use compatible hardware.

segment.source: Note that to take advantage of the limited-time free upgrade offer for PCs running Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1, you must leverage an in-place upgrade, either from Windows Update or by using the upgrade media available from the Windows 10 software download page to acquire a new Windows 10 license from the Windows Store.
segment.target: Note that to take advantage of the limited-time free upgrade offer for PCs running Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1, you must leverage an in-place upgrade, either from Windows Update or by using the upgrade media available from the Windows 10 software download page to acquire a new Windows 10 license from the Windows Store.

segment.source: For more information, refer to the Windows 10 FAQ.
segment.target: For more information, refer to the Windows 10 FAQ.

segment.source: For organizations with Software Assurance for Windows, both in-place upgrade or wipe-and-load can be leveraged (with in-place upgrade being the preferred method, as previously discussed).
segment.target: For organizations with Software Assurance for Windows, both in-place upgrade or wipe-and-load can be leveraged (with in-place upgrade being the preferred method, as previously discussed).

segment.source: For organizations that do not take advantage of the free upgrade offer and are not enrolled in Software Assurance for Windows, Windows 10 upgrade licenses are available for purchase through existing Volume License (VL) agreements.
segment.target: For organizations that do not take advantage of the free upgrade offer and are not enrolled in Software Assurance for Windows, Windows 10 upgrade licenses are available for purchase through existing Volume License (VL) agreements.

segment.source: Setup of new computers
segment.target: Setup of new computers

segment.source: For new computers acquired with Windows 10 preinstalled, you can leverage dynamic provisioning scenarios to transform the device from its initial state into a fully-configured organization PC.
segment.target: For new computers acquired with Windows 10 preinstalled, you can leverage dynamic provisioning scenarios to transform the device from its initial state into a fully-configured organization PC.

segment.source: There are two primary dynamic provisioning scenarios you can use:
segment.target: There are two primary dynamic provisioning scenarios you can use:

segment.source: User-driven, from the cloud.
segment.target: User-driven, from the cloud.

segment.source: By joining a device into Azure Active Directory and leveraging the automatic mobile device management (MDM) provisioning capabilities at the same time, an end user can initiate the provisioning process themselves just by entering the Azure Active Directory account and password (called their “work or school account” within Windows 10).
segment.target: By joining a device into Azure Active Directory and leveraging the automatic mobile device management (MDM) provisioning capabilities at the same time, an end user can initiate the provisioning process themselves just by entering the Azure Active Directory account and password (called their “work or school account” within Windows 10).

segment.source: The MDM service can then transform the device into a fully-configured organization PC.
segment.target: The MDM service can then transform the device into a fully-configured organization PC.

segment.source: For more information, see Azure Active Directory integration with MDM.
segment.target: For more information, see Azure Active Directory integration with MDM.

segment.source: IT admin-driven, using new tools.
segment.target: IT admin-driven, using new tools.

segment.source: Using the new Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool, IT administrators can create provisioning packages that can be applied to a computer to transform it into a fully-configured organization PC.
segment.target: Using the new Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool, IT administrators can create provisioning packages that can be applied to a computer to transform it into a fully-configured organization PC.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.

segment.source: In either of these scenarios, you can make a variety of configuration changes to the PC:
segment.target: In either of these scenarios, you can make a variety of configuration changes to the PC:

segment.source: Transform the edition (SKU) of Windows 10 that is in use.
segment.target: Transform the edition (SKU) of Windows 10 that is in use.

segment.source: Apply configuration and settings to the device (for example, security settings, device restrictions, policies, Wi-Fi and VPN profiles, certificates, and so on).
segment.target: Apply configuration and settings to the device (for example, security settings, device restrictions, policies, Wi-Fi and VPN profiles, certificates, and so on).

segment.source: Install apps, language packs, and updates.
segment.target: Install apps, language packs, and updates.

segment.source: Enroll the device in a management solution (applicable for IT admin-driven scenarios, configuring the device just enough to allow the management tool to take over configuration and ongoing management).
segment.target: Enroll the device in a management solution (applicable for IT admin-driven scenarios, configuring the device just enough to allow the management tool to take over configuration and ongoing management).

segment.source: Stay up to date
segment.target: Stay up to date

segment.source: For computers already running Windows 10 on the Current Branch or Current Branch for Business, new upgrades will periodically be deployed, approximately two to three times per year.
segment.target: For computers already running Windows 10 on the Current Branch or Current Branch for Business, new upgrades will periodically be deployed, approximately two to three times per year.

segment.source: You can deploy these upgrades by using a variety of methods:
segment.target: You can deploy these upgrades by using a variety of methods:

segment.source: Windows Update or Windows Update for Business, for devices where you want to receive updates directly from the Internet.
segment.target: Windows Update or Windows Update for Business, for devices where you want to receive updates directly from the Internet.

segment.source: Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), for devices configured to pull updates from internal servers after they are approved (deploying like an update).
segment.target: Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), for devices configured to pull updates from internal servers after they are approved (deploying like an update).

segment.source: Note that this will require updates to WSUS, which are only available for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2, not previous versions.
segment.target: Note that this will require updates to WSUS, which are only available for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2, not previous versions.

segment.source: System Center Configuration Manager task sequences (with Configuration Manager 2012, 2012 R2, and later versions).
segment.target: System Center Configuration Manager task sequences (with Configuration Manager 2012, 2012 R2, and later versions).

segment.source: System Center Configuration Manager vNext software update capabilities (deploying like an update).
segment.target: System Center Configuration Manager vNext software update capabilities (deploying like an update).

segment.source: Note that these upgrades (which are installed differently than monthly updates) will leverage an in-place upgrade process.
segment.target: Note that these upgrades (which are installed differently than monthly updates) will leverage an in-place upgrade process.

segment.source: Unlike updates, which are relatively small, these upgrades will include a full operating system image (around 3 GB for 64-bit operating systems), which requires time (1-2 hours) and disk space (approximately 10 GB) to complete.
segment.target: Unlike updates, which are relatively small, these upgrades will include a full operating system image (around 3 GB for 64-bit operating systems), which requires time (1-2 hours) and disk space (approximately 10 GB) to complete.

segment.source: Ensure that the deployment method you use can support the required network bandwidth and/or disk space requirements.
segment.target: Ensure that the deployment method you use can support the required network bandwidth and/or disk space requirements.

segment.source: Over time, this upgrade process will be optimized to reduce the overall time and network bandwidth consumed.
segment.target: Over time, this upgrade process will be optimized to reduce the overall time and network bandwidth consumed.
